"Gross direct premiums" as used in this section shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by section 9-21 of this article. 
(Ord. of 12-5-83, § 4; Ord. of 7-13-87; Ord. of 11-4-91, § 4) 
Sec. 9-25. - Gross premiums tax, all other insurers. 
There is hereby levied for the year 1992 and for each year thereafter an annual tax upon each insurer, other than an insurer transacting business in the class of insurance designated in subsection 1 of O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5, doing business within the city in an amount equal to two and one-half percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year, in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2. "Gross direct premiums" as used in this section shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2(a). 
(Ord. of 12-5-83, § 5; Ord. of 7-13-87; Ord. of 11-4-91, § 5) 
Sec. 9-26. - Due date for license fees. 
License fees imposed in sections 9-21, 9-22 and 9-23 of this article shall be due and payable on the tenth day of February, 1992 and on February 10 of each subsequent year. 
(Ord. of 12-5-83, § 6; Ord. of 7-13-87; Ord. of 11-4-91, § 6) 
Sec. 9-27. - Administrative provisions. 
The city clerk is hereby directed to forward a duly certified copy of this article to the insurance commissioner of the state within 45 days of its enactment. 
(Ord. of 11-4-91, § 7) 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Nov. 4, 1991, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, codification of § 7 of said ordinance as § 9-27 herein was at the editor's discretion. 
Secs. 9-28, 9-29. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RESERVED[2] 

Footnotes:

Editor's note— Section 1 of an ordinance adopted Feb. 13, 1995, repealed §§ 9-30—9-41 in their entirety. Formerly, §§ 9-30—9-41 pertained to billiard and pool halls, family recreation centers and derived from § 187 of the 1926 Code; §§ 1, 3—7, 9, 16 of Art. I and §§ 1, 2 of Art. II of an ordinance adopted July 18, 1977; an ordinance adopted Feb. 2, 1981; and an ordinance adopted July 13, 1987. 

Secs. 9-30—9-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BARTENDERS 

Sec. 9-50. - License required; approval, fee. 
All persons working in any tavern where alcoholic beverages may be consumed on the premises shall obtain a bartender's license from the city clerk after being approved by the chief of police. The fee for this license will be as set out in chapter 9, article I, subsection 9-3(a) herein. 
(Ord. of 12-30-99, § 1) 
Sec. 9-51. - Conviction of felony disqualifies. 
No person will be issued a bartender's license who has been convicted of a felony within the past five years. 
(Ord. of 12-30-99, § 1) 
Sec. 9-52. - Habitually offending disqualifies. 
No person will be issued a bartender's license, if during the preceding three years such person has been habitually offending against the laws of the state or ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. of 12-30-99, § 1) 
Sec. 9-53. - Appeal of license denial. 
The applicant may appeal the denial of a license to the governing body. 
(Ord. of 12-30-99, § 1) 
Sec. 9-54. - Suspension of bartender's license; causes, appeal. 
Any bartender guilty of any of the following will have such person's license suspended by the police department: 
(1)  Drinking while working 
(2)  Failing to call the police promptly when there is violence or the threat of violence in the establishment and including any disorderly act that originates in the establishment and continues outside within the close proximity of the establishment. 
(3)  Failure to cooperate with the police when they are investigating any complaint at or near the establishment. 
The suspension may be appealed to the governing body. 
(Ord. of 12-30-99, § 1) 
Sec. 9-55. - Suspension of establishment license. 
Any establishment which does not abide by this article may have the business license suspended by the police department until the next governing body meeting at which time the governing body will determine whether the license should be reinstated or revoked permanently. 
(Ord. of 12-30-99, § 1) 
Sec. 9-56. - Prosecution of offending bartenders and proprietors. 
Any person working without a bartender's license in an establishment covered by this article will be cited to court for violation of this article. The person holding the establishment's business license will be cited to court for permitting an unlicensed person to work in the establishment. 
(Ord. of 12-30-99, § 1) 
Secs. 9-57—9-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RESERVED[3] 

Footnotes:

ARTICLE IX. - GARAGE, YARD AND CARPORT SALES 

Sec. 9-130. - Scope of article. 
(a)  This article shall govern all sales usually defined as garage, yard or carport sales. 
(b)  For the purposes of this article, any sale of household goods conducted at a residential dwelling not considered a commercial establishment shall fall under the jurisdiction of this ordinance. 
( Ord. of 3-1-09(1), § 1 ) 
Sec. 9-131. - Permit-required. 
Every person desiring to conduct a garage, carport or yard sale within the city limits is required to produce a permit under the provisions of this article. 
Exception : Permit fees shall not be required for the following types of yard, carport or garage sales: 
(a)  Any nonprofit origination. 
(b)  Any benefit sale. 
(c)  Any senior citizen or disabled citizen. 
( Ord. of 3-1-09(1), § 1 ) 
Sec. 9-132. - Same—Application. 
(a)  Applications for permit shall be made to the city marshal at least seven days before said sale shall be scheduled. The application shall conform to the requirements of this ordinance and can be procured from the city marshal's office. 
(b)  Each application shall contain the following information. 
(1)  Name and address of the individual applying for the permit and at whose address said sale shall be held. 
(2)  Date said sale shall be conducted. 
(3)  Signature of the city marshal or zoning administrator approving the application. 
( Ord. of 3-1-09(1), § 1 ) 
Sec. 9-133. - Same—Fees. 
Upon issuance of the permit a fee of $15.00 shall be paid to the city marshal or zoning administrator to partially cover administrative costs involved in issuance and policing of this permit program. 
( Ord. of 3-1-09(1), § 1 ) 
Sec. 9-134. - Same—Period. 
The permit shall be issued only for a continuous 72 hour period and only one during any six-month period. No subsequent permit shall be issued to the place or person sooner than six months from the sale time. 
( Ord. of 3-1-09(1), § 1 ) 
Sec. 9-135. - Same—Display. 
The necessary permit shall be displayed in a prominent location at the site of the sale, easily observed from the public roadway at the address of the sale. 
( Ord. of 3-1-09(1), § 1 ) 
Sec. 9-136. - Parking. 
Sufficient parking area shall be available to allow access to the sale without interfering with the flow of traffic. 
( Ord. of 3-1-09(1), § 1 ) 
Sec. 9-137. - Setback of items from street. 
Household goods offered for sale shall not be placed on display after six p.m. or any closer to a public roadway than setback requirements of the zoning district in which the sale is conducted. 
( Ord. of 3-1-09(1), § 1 ) 
Sec. 9-138. - Signs. 
(a)  Only one sign no larger than four square feet shall be displayed at the location of such sale which shall be set back from the roadway at least ten feet. 
In addition, only two directional signs no larger than two square feet shall be allowed for the purpose of directing traffic to the sale location. 
(b)  At the conclusion of the sale all signs shall be taken down by the individual whose name appears on the permit. 
( Ord. of 3-1-09(1), § 1 ) 
Sec. 9-139. - Penalties. 
Any person required by the provisions of this article to obtain a permit for the conduct of a garage, carport, yard or similar sale but who does not obtain said permit, or who fails to abide by any requirements of this article, may be stopped or enjoined from carrying on such sale and charged with a misdemeanor and fined $100.00 for each violation of the ordinance. 
( Ord. of 3-1-09(1), § 1 ) 
ARTICLE X. - RESERVED[7] 

Footnotes:

Editor's note— Ord. of 10-18-10(1), § 1, adopted October 18, 2010 , repealed article X, §§ 9-140—9-146, which pertained to wine and derived from rd. of 10-7-91, §§ 1—6; Ord. of 5-4-2009, § 5. 

Secs. 9-140—9-149. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - FLEA MARKETS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Nov. 1, 1993, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, codification of §§ I—X of said ordinance as §§ 9-150—9-159 herein was at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 9-150. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the following terms shall have the following meanings, unless the context clearly indicates that a different meaning is intended. 
Flea market: A market, indoors or out-of-doors, where new or used items are sold from individual locations, with each location being operated independently from the other locations. Items sold include but are not limited to household items, antiques, rare items, decorations, used books and used magazines. 
Flea market seller A person, firm or corporation selling items or offering items for sale at a flea market. 
Market: A place where goods are sold to the public. 
(Ord. of 11-1-93, § I) 
Sec. 9-151. - License required. 
No person, firm or corporation shall operate the business of renting space or allocating space to flea market sellers without first obtaining a license therefor. Applications for licenses shall be made to the city clerk on forms to be provided by the city clerk. Only one license shall be required for each flea market, and the individual flea market sellers shall not be responsible or required to obtain a license under this section. The fee for such license shall be $200.00 per year. 
(Ord. of 11-1-93, § II) 
Sec. 9-152. - Records to be kept by licensee. 
Each person required by this article to obtain a license shall keep accurate records of the names and addresses of each flea market seller together with a brief description of the type of merchandise offered for sale by that seller. 
(Ord. of 11-1-93, § III) 
Sec. 9-153. - Secondhand stores excepted. 
No person, firm or corporation having a license as a secondhand store shall be required to obtain a license under this article for the same business location. 
(Ord. of 11-1-93, § IV) 
Sec. 9-154. - More than one market. 
Any person, firm or corporation renting or allocating space to flea market sellers in more than one place of business shall be required to obtain a license for each place of business provided that one license shall be adequate for locations that are on the same lot, adjacent lots or lots separated only by an alley. 
(Ord. of 11-1-93, § V) 
Sec. 9-155. - Unlawful transactions. 
No person shall sell or offer for sale at any flea market any goods known to be stolen. Firearms, ammunition, and related items are prohibited without proper permits. 
(Ord. of 11-1-93, § VI) 
Sec. 9-156. - Purchases from children. 
No flea market seller shall purchase any used household item, antique or used article whatsoever from any person under the age of 18 years unless such person is accompanied by the person's parent or guardian. 
(Ord. of 11-1-93, § VII) 
Sec. 9-157. - Penalty. 
Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $1,000.00 for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. of 11-1-93, § VIII) 
Sec. 9-158. - Public display. 
There shall be no display of merchandise after 6:00 p.m. daily, except in the following instances: 
When items to be sold are so large as to make it economically impossible to completely weatherproof those items such as boats, cars, and trailers. These shall be enclosed by a privacy fence that allows limited view from the street, such fences shall be subject to the approval of the building inspector. Display material shall not be kept outside after business hours. 
(Ord. of 11-1-93, § IX) 
Sec. 9-159. - Attendant. 
The licensee shall provide a fulltime adult attendant upon the licensed premises during business hours. The attendant will be responsible for keeping the vendor log and notifying the city of any illegal activity. 
(Ord. of 11-1-93, § X) 
ARTICLE XII. - GOING-OUT-OF-BUSINESS SALES 

Sec. 9-160. - Purpose and intent. 
The city finds and declares that the provisions of the ordinance codified in this chapter are necessary to further significant city interests in that: 
(a)  Prolonged liquidation or "going out of business" sales could tend to create, or leave the impression of, blighted or economically depressed conditions in and around the location of the sale; and 
(b)  Liquidation or forced sales are frequently characterized by large banners or signs which can result in visual blight, and the presence of a large number of persons which can result in traffic congestion, noise, and litter. 
(c)  The city's public officer or designee will regulate, license, and monitor this form of business to protect consumers from misleading or fraudulent practices. The law prohibits conducting a going-out-of-business sale for more than 90 days. After this time limit has expired, it is against the law to do business in any other manner contrary to representations that were made about the nature of the sale. 
( Ord. of 11-5-12(1) ) 
State Law reference— O.C.G.A. 10-1-393(b)(24) 
Sec. 9-161. - Exceptions. 
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to, affect, the following: 
(a)  Estate sales by an authorized agent of the deceased, according to the law or by the provisions of the will; 
(b)  Sales of property conveyed by security deed, deed of trust, mortgage or judgment, or ordered to be sold according to the deed, mortgage or judgment order; 
(c)  Sales of all agricultural produce and livestock arising from the labor of the seller or other labor under the seller's control, on or belonging to the seller's property, and not purchased or sold for speculation; 
(d)  All sales under legal process; 
(e)  Sales by a pawnbroker or loan company selling or offering for sale unredeemed pledges of goods, as provided by law; and 
(f)  Sales of automobiles by an auctioneer licensed under the laws of the state of Georgia; 
(g)  Duly licensed auctioneers selling at an auction; 
( Ord. of 11-5-12(1) ) 
Sec. 9-162. - Going out of business requirements. 
(a)  Restriction on stock offered for sale: The stock offered for sale by any person under the designation of "closing out of business sale," "discontinuance of business sale," or "removal sale," or under any other description of like meaning, not involving bankruptcy or insolvency, shall be held to include only the goods, wares, furniture, fixtures, jewelry, merchandise or personal property actually in the stock or place of business of the person conducting the sale, at the operating of the sale. 
(b)  Adding to stock: It shall be unlawful to add to the stock, under the provisions of this article, by shipping in goods, wares or merchandise from the other sources, unless such replenishment is publicly advertised or clearly indicated as such by items. 
(c)  Change of ownership not to affect status of sale: No change of ownership of the goods, wares, furniture, fixtures, jewelry, merchandise or property offered in sale as prescribed in this article and no change of ownership of the capital stock of a corporation conducting such sale shall affect the status of the sale as a governed by this article. 
If an owner of a place of business discontinues the business, the owner can not reopen at the same location, under the same ownership and name of the closed business for six months. 
(d)  Misrepresenting sales: Any person advertising by newspaper, radio, posters, or otherwise, representing that he/she is operating, offering or maintaining fire sales, wreck sales, bankrupt sales, closing out or going out of business sales, removal sales and similar businesses, whereby the public is led to believe that they are being offered merchandise at reduced rates on account of fires, wrecks, bankruptcies, or closing out or discontinuance of business, when in fact such sales are not bona fide, but are fakes and frauds, and the advertisements and representations are untrue and false, shall be held guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable, upon conviction, in accordance to this ordinance, and each day that such sale of business is conducted in violation of the terms of this section shall constitute as separate offense. 
( Ord. of 11-5-12(1) ) 
Sec. 9-163. - Permit required. 
(1)  No person shall conduct any sale without first having obtained a permit from the city to conduct the sale; 
(2)  An application for the permit required by this chapter shall be filed with city hall at least 20 days prior to the date on which the sale is commenced; 
(3)  The application shall be accompanied by a fee of $15.00 and a permit fee of $50.00, as established by resolution of the city mayor and council; 
(4)  The application shall be signed and under penalty of perjury, by the person conducting the sale or by an authorized representative of the business entity conducting the sale; 
(5)  The application shall contain the following information; 
(6)  The address of the location at which the sale is to be conducted; 
(7)  The dates and times during which the sale is to be conducted; 
(8)  The type of ownership of the business and, if other than a sole proprietorship, the position held with the business entity by the person signing the application; 
(9)  The reason for, and the nature of, the sale; 
(10)  An inventory statement setting forth the quantity and description of all goods and merchandise to be sold at the sale with sufficient information to permit identification of the goods and merchandise upon inspection; 
(11)  Such other information as the public officer or designee may deem necessary in determining whether to issue the permit; 
(12)  At the time the application is filed, applicant shall grant permission to the public officer to enter, during normal business hours, the property or premises on which the sale is to be conducted for the purpose of verifying the accuracy of the inventory statement required by this article; 
(13)  The public officer or designee shall grant the permit upon a determination that the statements in the application are true and the proposed sale does not violate and city ordinance or state law. The decision to grant or deny the permit shall be made at least ten days prior to scheduled commencement of the sale. The public officer may impose conditions on the permit as are necessary or appropriate to protect the interests of the city and persons residing or working near the location of the sale. 
( Ord. of 11-5-12(1) ) 
Sec. 9-164. - Permit/term and conditions: 
A permit issued by the public officer to the first application shall be valid for period of 60 days, and shall be subject to the conditions specified in this article and conditions imposed by the public officer. Business's participating in these types of sales will be required to obtain a permit from the city's land use and development office. 
(a)  Permits shall be issued only one permit per year, to approved applicants. No subsequent permit shall be issued to a business to extend or any sooner than one year; 
(b)  All permits issued pursuant to this chapter shall be subject to the following conditions; 
(c)  The permittee shall comply with all applicable city ordinances and state laws; 
(d)  Permittee shall sell only the goods specified in the original inventory or the statement describing goods ordered, but not received; 
(e)  Permittee shall not engage in a false, fraudulent or deceptive business practice in the conduct of the sale; and advertising shall not be no more than 90 days as state law requires; 
(f)  Additional conditions may be imposed on the permit subsequent to issuance if, in the opinion of the public officer, those conditions are necessary or appropriate to protect in the interests of the city or persons residing or working near the location of the sale; 
(g)  A permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall not be transferable; 
( Ord. of 11-5-12(1) ) 
Sec. 9-165. - Enforcement/violations. 
Individuals, businesses and practitioners who fail or refuse to make available truthful and accurate statements the city request or requires, for determining applicability information needed to comply with the provisions of this chapter, or conditions imposed on the permit, the city will revoke or will ask to surrender the business license issued to him/her for the business being discontinued. 
Any person who neglects or refuses to comply with any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction therefore, shall be fined not less than $100.00 or more than $1,000.00, and each day of continued violation after conviction shall constitute a separate offense. 
( Ord. of 11-5-12(1) ) 
Sec. 9-166. - Appeals process. 
The applicant may appeal the denial of a license to the governing body, by filing a written appeal with the city clerk within five business days after the date of the denial notice. The city council shall hear the appeal and shall render a decision within five business days of the hearing. 
The decisions of the city mayor and council shall be final. 
( Ord. of 11-5-12(1) ) 
State Law reference— Georgia's Fair Business Practices Act (FBPA), O.C.G.A. § 10-393(b)(24).
