Chapter 10 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Alcoholic beverages—Drinking on public, school or recreation property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drink or consume any alcoholic beverage on any street or other right-of-way within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drink or consume any alcoholic beverage on school grounds and recreation properties in the city. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to consume any alcoholic beverage outside of any place of business or parking lot thereof, which place of business sells any alcoholic beverage. 
(d)  It shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section where any person is in the possession of any alcoholic beverage in an unsealed container in any of the places aforementioned. 
(Ord. of 6-23-80, §§ 1, 2) 
State Law reference— Possession on school grounds, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-21.1; public intoxication, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41. 
Sec. 10-2. - Same—Being drunk and disorderly. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to be drunk and disorderly in the city. 
(Code 1926, § 177) 
State Law reference— Authority of city to so provide, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41. 
Sec. 10-3. - Damaging city property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to maliciously damage, deface, break or destroy any property of the city. 
(Code 1926, § 234) 
State Law reference— Criminal damage to property, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-22 et seq. 
Sec. 10-4. - Damaging, etc., electric poles, etc. 
It shall be an offense to cut, break, or in any other manner damage or interfere with any telegraph, telephone, electric light or other pole in the city used for the support of electric wires, or to throw at, break or in any other manner damage or interfere with any fixture, wire, lamp or other thing placed thereon; or to tie any horse, mule or other animal of any sort to any such pole. 
(Code 1926, § 229) 
State Law reference— Damaging utility property, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25. 
Sec. 10-5. - Damaging property in parks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to leave the walks laid out in any public park and trespass upon the grass, or to deface any of the seats, fountains or other property therein by cutting or whittling thereon with a knife or other instrument, or by writing or marking thereon with a pen, pencil or other instrument, or to cut or damage any of the shade trees in such park. 
(Code 1926, § 225) 
Sec. 10-6. - Cutting trees; trespass on public lots. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to cut down any tree, or otherwise trespass on any public lot or square in the city. 
(Code 1926, § 195) 
Sec. 10-7. - Attaching signs, etc., on public property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to tack, nail or otherwise affix any paper, cardboard, tin, sign or any other thing upon any utility pole, post, or any other thing upon any street or sidewalk right-of-way within the city. 
(Ord. of 10-3-60) 
Cross reference— Sign permits, § 4-5, App. A, Art. IX, § D. 
Sec. 10-8. - Attaching signs to trees. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to tack or nail any paper, cardboard, tin or any other thing upon any shade tree within the city. 
(Code 1926, § 198) 
Sec. 10-9. - Quarreling, etc. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to be guilty of quarreling or otherwise acting in a disorderly manner. 
(Code 1926, § 176) 
State Law reference— Fighting, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-32. 
Sec. 10-10. - Discharging firearm. 
It shall not be lawful to shoot any gun, pistol or other firearms within the city except by permission of the mayor and mayor pro tem, or three members of the governing body. 
(Code 1926, § 178) 
Sec. 10-11. - Obscene language. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to be guilty of using obscene language, publicly and loudly, in the hearing of others, in the city. 
(Code 1926, § 179) 
Sec. 10-12. - Lewdness. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to be guilty of open lewdness or any notorious act of public indecency, tending to debauch the morals, within the city. 
(Code 1926, § 180) 
State Law reference— Public indecency, O.C.G.A. § 16-6-8. 
Sec. 10-13. - Contempt of council. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to be guilty of contemptuous or disorderly conduct towards the governing body, or in its presence. 
(Code 1926, § 188) 
Sec. 10-14. - Throwing objects. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to pitch, throw, or cast any stone or missile at or upon any house, window, lamp, electric light or telephone pole or fixture, or shade tree. 
(Code 1926, § 189) 
Sec. 10-15. - Business establishments engaged in retail sale of alcoholic beverages; minors. 
(a)  For purposes of this section, the term "business establishment primarily engaged in the retail sale of alcoholic beverages" means an individual, partnership, corporation, association, or other business entity which derives from its retail sale of alcoholic beverages at least 75 percent of its total annual gross income. 
(b)  No one under the age of 21 years shall enter or remain on the premises of any business establishment engaged in the retail sale of alcoholic beverages in unbroken packages or by the drink, nor shall any business establishment primarily engaged in the retail sale of alcoholic beverages in unbroken packages or by the drink, permit anyone under the age of 21 years to enter into or remain on its business premises. 
(Ord. of 3-6-95) 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Mar. 6, 1995, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, codification of substantive provisions of said ordinance as § 10-15 herein was at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 10-16. - Loitering. 
It shall be unlawful for any two or more persons to loiter, to congregate, to gather, or to remain in or near any public right-of-way or other place open to the public in a manner and under such circumstances manifesting the purpose of creating a public nuisance, creating loud noises, or otherwise disturbing the peace in any manner, including, but not limited to fighting, riotous conduct, and/or obstructing in any manner the free passage of the general public in going to or from, or in or out, of such places of public accommodation. 
(Ord. of 12-10-2001, § 1) 
Sec. 10-17. - Penalties for violation. 
Unless otherwise specifically set forth therein, the penalty for the violation of all ordinances of the city shall be as follows: Any person violating any provision of the Code of Ordinances of the city shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 or by imprisonment in the city jail for not more than 60 days, or both. 
(Ord. of 12-10-2001, § 2) 
Sec. 10-18. - Garage, yard and carport sales within the city. 
(a)  Definitions. This section shall govern all sales usually defined as garage, yard or carport sales. For the purposes of this section, any sale of household goods conducted at a residential dwelling not considered a commercial establishment shall fall under the jurisdiction of this section. 
(b)  Applications for permit. Every person desiring to conduct a garage, carport or yard sale within the city limits is required to procure a permit under the provisions of this section. Applications for permit shall be made to the city building inspector at least seven days before said sale shall be scheduled. The application shall conform to the requirements of this section and can be procured from the city building inspector's office. 
(c)  Contents for application of permit. Each application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of the individual applying for the permit and at whose address said sale shall be held. 
(2)  Date said sale shall be conducted. 
(3)  Signature/stamp of the building inspector approving the application. 
(d)  Fees. Upon issuance of the permit a fee of $15.00 shall be paid to the city building inspector to partially cover administrative costs involved in issuance and policing of this permit program. 
(e)  General requirements. 
(1)  After procurement of the necessary permit, said permit shall be displayed in a prominent location at the site of the sale easily observed from the public roadway at the address of the sale. 
(2)  Said permit shall only be issued for a continuous 72-hour period during any six-month period. No subsequent permit shall be issued to the place or person sooner than six months from the sale time. 
(3)  Sufficient parking area shall be available to allow access to sale without interfering with the flow of traffic. 
(4)  Household goods offered for sale shall not be placed on display any closer to a public roadway than setback requirements of the zoning district in which the sale is conducted. 
(5)  Only one sign no larger than four square feet shall be displayed at the location of such sale which shall be set back from the roadway at least ten feet. In addition, only two directional signs no larger than two square feet shall be allowed for the purpose of directing traffic to the sale location. 
(6)  At the conclusion of the sale all signs shall be taken down by the individual whose name appears on the permit. 
(Ord. of 7-7-1997, §§ 1—5) 
Secs. 10-19—10-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RULES REGARDING CHATSWORTH CITY PARK 

Sec. 10-36. - Rules concerning park. 
(a)  Park hours: 
(1)  The Chatsworth City Park, consisting of the city block located at the northeast intersection of Second Avenue and Peachtree Street shall be closed to the public each evening from 11:00 p.m. until 5:00 a.m. the following day. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to be present at the Chatsworth City Park during the hours of 11:01 p.m. until 4:59 a.m. the following day. 
(b)  Alcoholic beverages are prohibited in the park. 
(c)  No organized games or team sports are allowed inside the park. 
(d)  Bicycles, skate boards, roller blades and roller skates are prohibited in the park. 
(e)  Swimming or wading in the fountain is prohibited. 
(f)  All dogs must have immunization tags on collars and must be on a leash and must be under the complete control of the owner at all times. 
(Ord. of 9-11-2000, § 1; Ord. of 9-9-2002, §§ I, II) 
Sec. 10-37. - Preserving natural beauty of park. 
(a)  All trash or litter is to be placed in designated containers. 
(b)  Plants, trees and all other landscape is not to be defaced, destroyed or removed. 
(c)  It is unlawful to offer items for sale in the park. 
(Ord. of 9-11-2000, § 2) 
Sec. 10-38. - Provisions for violations. 
Any person who violates any subsection of this ordinance shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as follows: 
(1)  Upon first offense: 
a.  By a fine of not less than $50.00 nor more than $100.00, or 
b.  By having to perform a certain number of hours of designated community service not to exceed 40 hours; or 
c.  By both subsections (a) and (b) under this first offense; 
(2)  Upon second offense: 
a.  By a fine of not less than $100.00 nor more than $300.00; or 
b.  By having to perform a certain number of hours of community service not to exceed 100 hours; or 
c.  By both subsections (a) and (b) under this second offense. 
d.  Enforcement of this article may be accomplished by the city in any manner authorized by law. 
(3)  Pursuant to the provisions contained in O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20(b), the maximum punishment for violation of this article shall not exceed a fine of $500.00 or imprisonment for ten days, or both. 
(Ord. of 9-11-2000, § 3; Ord. of 9-9-2002, § III) 
Secs. 10-39—10-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FALSE ALARMS 

Sec. 10-51. - Definitions. 
Automatic dialing device means any device connected to an alarm system which automatically sends a pre-recorded message or coded signal indicating the activation of the alarm system to a predetermined location. 
Automatic response alarms systems means a device intended to detect and signal intrusion in a closed premise or upon a premise or to signal a robbery, in which signal and alarm system business, monitoring station or other entity. 
False alarm means the activation of a burglary and/or robbery alarm at a time when no burglary or robbery is being committed or attempted on the premises. 
Independent alarm system means a device intended to detect and signal intrusion into a closed premise or a robbery, in which does not automatically signal an alarm system business, monitoring station or other entity. 
Multiple alarm sites means more than one alarm system on the premise. 
Response means the dispatch of the Chatsworth Police Department or members of the Chatsworth Fire Department, either paid or volunteer, to the premise where an alarm system has been activated indicating a burglary and/or robbery in progress on those premises. 
(Ord. of 9-9-2002, § 1) 
Sec. 10-52. - Automatic dialers: automatic response alarm systems. 
It shall be unlawful to key automatic dialer burglar alarms or robbery alarms, or any automatic response alarm system (burglary or robbery) to any Chatsworth Police Department telephone number, including 911, or location. Such alarm shall only be keyed to a private answering service who can then notify the Chatsworth Police Department or 911. 
(Ord. of 9-9-2002, § 2) 
Sec. 10-53. - False alarms. 
Fees for response. Per Chatsworth Police Department's response to any false alarm of any automatic alarm response system or independent alarm system, the Chatsworth Police Chief or his lawful officers shall charge and collect from the person, business or legal entity, using or maintaining the automatic response alarm system or independent alarm system, fees as follows: 
(1)  For a first or second response to a premises at which no other false alarm has occurred within a calendar year, no fee shall be charged. 
(2)  For a third response to a false alarm within a calendar year, no fees shall be charged, but notice shall be given to the person or business using or maintaining the alarm system of the false alarms and the requirements of this article, including the fee requirement for any subsequent response to a false alarm response by the Chatsworth Police Department within the calendar year. 
(3)  Upon a fourth response to a false alarm at the premises within a calendar year, a fee of $50.00 shall be charged to the person occupying the premises. 
(4)  Upon a fifth response to a false alarm within the calendar year, a fee of $75.00 shall be charged; and for all succeeding responses within the calendar year a fee of $100.00 shall be charged per response. 
(Ord. of 9-9-2002, § 3) 
Sec. 10-54. - Automatic cutoff system. 
All audible alarms, sirens, bells, or horns shall have an automatic cutoff so that the alarm will not operate for more than 30 minutes after activation. 
(Ord. of 9-9-2002, § 4) 
Sec. 10-55. - Penalties. 
Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this article shall be fined as provided by section 10-53 above by the Chatsworth Municipal Court of the City of Chatsworth, Georgia for each such offense. No fine or penalty shall be assessed for acts of God, nature or beyond control as determined in the sole discretion of the Chatsworth Police Officer responding to the alarm. 
(Ord. of 9-9-2002, § 5) 
Secs. 10-56—10-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TELEGRAPH OR TELEPHONE COMPANY 

Sec. 10-61. - Due compensation for telephone companies with end user retail customers within the city. 
(a)  The City of Chatsworth hereby requires due compensation of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues, as defined in paragraphs (8) and (9) of subsection (b) of Section 46-5-1 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated; provided, however, that any company which pays in excess of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues pursuant to an existing franchise agreement shall continue to pay in accordance with the agreement until the expiration of the franchise agreement or December 31, 2012, whichever occurs first, and any company which pays in excess of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues in accordance with an occupational license tax arrangement shall continue to pay in accordance with such payment schedule until December 31, 2012. 
(b)  Regarding any telephone company that does not have retail, end user customers located within the city's municipal boundaries, the payment by such company to a municipal authority in accordance with the rates set by regulations promulgated by the department of transportation for the use of its rights of way shall be considered the payment of due compensation. 
( Ord. of 7-6-09(1), § 1 ) 
Chapter 11 - PERSONNEL 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 11-1—11-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SOCIAL SECURITY 

Sec. 11-20. - Election of coverages. 
It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend at the earliest date possible under the agreement entered into by the state and the federal social security administration, to the employees and officials thereof, and its instrumentalities, not excluded by law or by this article, the benefits of the system of old-age and survivors insurance as authorized by the federal social security act, the state enabling act, and amendments thereto. In pursuance of such policy, and for that purpose, the city shall take such action as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Ord. of 6-6-60, § 1; Ord. No. 8-1-77, § 1) 
Sec. 11-21. - Execution of agreements. 
The mayor, or other chief executive officer of the city, is hereby authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with employees' retirement system of the state for coverage of such employees and officials as provided in section 11-20, including firemen, that are in positions covered by a public retirement system, in the manner by such law provided. 
(Ord. of 6-6-60, § 2; Ord. of 8-1-77, § 2) 
Sec. 11-22. - Withholdings. 
Withholdings from salaries and wages of employees and officials for the purpose provided for in section 11-20 hereof are hereby authorized to be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the state agency. 
(Ord. of 6-6-60, § 3; Ord. of 8-1-77, § 3) 
Sec. 11-23. - Contributions. 
There shall be appropriated from general funds such amounts at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations for employer's contributions, and administrative expenses, and such funds shall be paid over to the employees' retirement system of the state in accordance with regulations established by such agency. 
(Ord. of 6-6-60, § 4; Ord. of 8-1-77, § 4) 
Sec. 11-24. - Records and reports. 
The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Ord. of 6-6-60, § 5; Ord. of 8-1-77, § 5) 
Sec. 11-25. - Unauthorized persons excluded. 
There is hereby excluded from this article any authority to make any agreement with respect to any position, or any employee or official not authorized to be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Ord. of 6-6-60, § 6; Ord. of 8-1-77, § 6) 
Sec. 11-26. - Amendment to plan—Release of escrow deposits. 
The mayor, or other designated official of the city, is hereby authorized and directed to execute an agreement amending the original plan and agreement with the employees' retirement system of the state, in substantially the form attached to the ordinance from which this section is derived, as Exhibit ``A,'' providing for the release of social security escrow deposits. 
(Ord. of 3-2-81, § 1) 
Sec. 11-27. - Same—Abiding by rules. 
The city agrees to abide by the rules and regulations of the employees' retirement system of the state, hereinafter called the state agency, in regard to collections from city employees in making reports and payments to the state agency. 
(Ord. of 3-2-81, § 2) 
Sec. 11-28. - Same—Pledging amounts by city. 
The city hereby pledges an amount which it would receive in state grant funds as security for assurance that it will make collections from its employees, submit required reports, and remit payments to the state agency as agreed to in its plan of coverage of employees for social security benefits. The city further agrees that if the amount of state grant funds which it is entitled to receive in a calendar year is less than its annual payment to the state agency, as may be determined by the state agency, then, the city shall deposit in escrow, when so notified in writing by the state agency and in accordance with its rules and regulations, an amount which, when added to the city's state great funds, would total an amount sufficient to meet its obligations of reporting and remitting collections to the state agency. 
(Ord. of 3-2-81, § 3) 
Secs. 11-29—11-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RETIREMENT PLAN 

Sec. 11-40. - Adopted by reference. 
A retirement plan for the employees of the City of Chatsworth, Georgia, the joint trust agreement and the contract for the administration of said plan by the city and the Georgia Municipal Employees Benefit System as provided by O.C.G.A. section 47-5-1 et seq., is adopted by reference herein as if fully set out. 
(Ord. of 9-10-90(2), § 1) 
Chapter 12 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— For zoning procedures law, see O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1 et seq. 

Sec. 12-1. - Municipal planning commission—Created; membership; organization. 
There is created a municipal planning commission, with powers as authorized by law. This commission shall be known as the City of Chatsworth Planning Commission and it shall consist of five members who are citizens of this city. The commission members shall serve terms varying from one to five years when first organized, and as terms expire the appointments shall be for five-year periods. All appointments to the commission, compensation to members, adoption into law of the recommendations of the commission shall be made by the governing body as authorized by law. 
(Ord. of 6-2-58) 
Sec. 12-2. - Same—Duties. 
During the first year of operation, the commission shall have studied the basic problems of land use, the problems of existing thoroughfares and traffic congestion, of existing community facilities and public improvements, shall have made recommendations concerning the adoption of subdivision regulations, and shall have made recommendations concerning a master plan, and the adoption and protection thereof. It shall have such duties as provided by law or ordinance. 
(Ord. of 6-2-58) 
Sec. 12-3. - Joint planning commission—Established. 
The city hereby establishes the Chatsworth-Murray County Joint Planning Commission. 
(Ord. of 5-20-74) 
Sec. 12-4. - Same—Membership. 
The joint planning commission shall consist of nine members; four members shall be residents of this city appointed by the governing body of the city; and one member shall be a resident of the City of Eton, appointed by the governing body of that city; and four members shall be residents of the county appointed by the governing body of the county. The terms of the members shall be for four years, except that the initial members appointed by the city shall have served for terms ending December 31, 1974; December 31, 1975; December 31, 1976; and December 31, 1977, respectively; their successors thereafter to serve for full four-year terms. Any vacancy in membership appointed by the city shall be filled for the unexpired term by the governing body of the city, which shall also have the authority to remove any city-appointed member for cause, on written charges, after a public hearing. All members shall serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. 
(Ord. of 5-20-74, § 1) 
Sec. 12-5. - Same—Organization, rules, staff; finances. 
The joint planning commission shall elect its chairman from among its members. The term of chairman shall be one year with eligibility for reelection. The joint planning commission shall appoint a secretary who may be an officer or employee of either municipality or the county. The planning commission shall make its own rules of procedure and determine its time of meeting. All meetings of the joint planning commission at which official action is taken shall be open to the public and all records of the joint planning commission shall be a public record. The planning commission may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its work and may contract with the state planning agency and city planners and other consultants for such services as it may require. The expenditures of the joint planning commission, exclusive of gifts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for the purpose by the governing body of the cities and county. 
(Ord. of 5-20-74, § 2) 
Sec. 12-6. - Same—Powers and duties. 
When the joint planning commission shall have organized and selected its officers, and shall have adopted its rule of procedure, then it shall have all the powers, duties and responsibilities set forth in O.C.G.A. § 36-66-2. 
(Ord. of 5-20-74, § 3) 
Sec. 12-7. - Area planning commission—Created and established. 
In order to guide and accomplish a coordinated and harmonious development of the municipality and the northwest Georgia area which will, in accordance with existing and future needs, best promote public health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity, and the general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development, that the Coosa Valley Area Planning and Development Commission, hereinafter referred to as the area planning commission, is hereby created and established as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 36-66-2. 
(Ord. of 12-29-60) 
Sec. 12-8. - Same—Membership. 
The area planning commission shall consist of two members from each of the counties participating in the area planning commission. Of the members from each county, one shall be appointed by the governing body of the municipality wherein the county seat is located and the other member shall be appointed by the governing authority of the county. The term of office for all members shall be five years, except that the initial appointment by the governing body of this city shall be for a term of four years. Any vacancy in the membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by the governing body making the appointment which has become vacant. The appointing authority shall also have the power to remove any member it may appoint for cause, or written charges, after public hearing. All members shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. of 12-29-60, §§ 1, 2) 
Sec. 12-9. - Same—Organization; rules; staff; finances. 
The area planning commission shall elect a chairman and vice chairman from among its appointive members. The term of office of the chairman and vice chairman shall be for one year or until reelected or their successors are elected. The commission shall appoint a secretary who may be an employee of the commission. The commission shall meet at least once each month at the call of the chairman and at such other time as the chairman or board may determine, shall adopt rules for the transaction of business and shall keep a record of its resolutions, or transactions, findings, and determinations, which record shall be a public record. The commission may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its work. In the performance of its duties, the commission may cooperate with, contract with, or accept funds from federal, state, or local public or semipublic agencies or private individuals or corporations, may spend such funds, and may carry out such cooperative undertakings and contracts. It may make expenditures for the purchase of required equipment and supplies. The expenditures of the commission, exclusive of gifts to the commission and contract receipts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for the purpose by the participating governing authorities. 
(Ord. of 12-29-60, § 3) 
Sec. 12-10. - Same—Powers and duties. 
It shall be the function and duty of the commission to make such careful and comprehensive surveys and studies of existing conditions and probable future developments and to prepare such plans for physical, social, and economic growth as will best promote the public health, safety, morals, convenience, prosperity, or the general welfare as well as efficiency and economy in the development of the entire northwest Georgia area and each political subdivision therein. In general, the commission shall have such powers and duties and responsibilities as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 36-66-2. 
(Ord. of 12-29-60, § 4) 
Chapter 13 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Restoration of street surface after sewer connection, § 8-51(c). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13-1. - Street dedication requirements. 
(a)  All future roads, streets and/or major thoroughfares dedicated and conveyed to the city for public use shall have a width of right-of-way of not less than 60 feet. 
(b)  Such dedications and conveyances shall grant the city the right to slope banks, make fills and construct drainage ditches for short distances back of the right-of-way lines where necessary for the proper construction and maintenance of such roads, streets and/or thoroughfares. 
(c)  Such dedications and conveyances of roads, streets and/or thoroughfares shall be in compliance with minimum design standards set forth in the city-county subdivision regulations. 
(Ord. of 5-1-72) 
Sec. 13-2. - Removal of dirt. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to dig or haul any dirt from any street or other ground of the city, without permission of the governing body. 
(Code 1926, § 192) 
Sec. 13-3. - Private use; placing obstructions. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to convert any pubic street in the city to such person's use, or place any obstruction thereon, such as wood, barrels, boxes, timber or lumber, except necessarily for building purposes. Any such obstruction shall be moved by the city at the expense of the owner thereof. 
(Code 1926, § 193) 
Sec. 13-4. - Placing objects on sidewalks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain on any sidewalk any goods, wares or merchandise, vegetables or fruits, or place any barrels, boxes or other articles on such sidewalk, except within three feet from the wall of such person's house or store. 
(Code 1926, § 199) 
Sec. 13-5. - Obstructing drains. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to fill up any ditch or drain in any of the streets of the city or purposely place any obstruction therein to prevent the free flow of water. 
(Code 1926, § 194) 
Sec. 13-6. - Street design and specifications. 
Prior to dedication and acceptance thereof by the city, all city streets shall be constructed to meet the following minimum standards: 
(1)  The base shall be constructed to a compacted depth of not less than six inches graded aggregate base (G.A.B.) pug mix. 
(2)  All drainage piping within any city right-of-way shall be concrete class 3 or metal, which shall be fully asphalt coated. 
(3)  All pipe, including utilities, shall be compacted to not less than 95 percent. Graded aggregate base shall be compacted to not less than 97 percent. 
(4)  All paving shall require a two inch minimum asphalt concrete binder type B and one and one-half inches minimum asphalt concrete topping E or F mix. 
(5)  All streets shall have a painted double center line unless directed in writing otherwise by the road superintendent. 






(Ord. of 4-10-2006, § 1; Ord. of 3-3-2008, App. D) 
Sec. 13-7. - Street solicitations. 
(a)  General; permit required. No person shall sell any goods or services in, along, upon or over the public streets, roads, alleys or thoroughfares of the city unless specifically allowed elsewhere in this code and no person shall solicit for the contribution of money for charitable purposes in, along, upon or over the public streets, roads, alleys or thoroughfares of the city unless such person shall have a permit from the city for such purpose. The foregoing sentence shall not be applicable to duly licensed vendors of goods sold from rolling vendors. 
(b)  Permit requirements and process. The chief of the Chatsworth Police Department or his delegate may issue a permit to an (sic) person petitioning to solicit for the contribution of money for charitable purposes in, along, upon, or over the public streets, roads, alleys or thoroughfares of the city in the following circumstances: 
(1)  The person or persons petitioning must be joined in their petition by a sponsoring organization which is a qualified charitable organization recognized as such by the Internal Revenue Service under section 501 (c) (3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended, and where the solicitation is purely for raising funds for a stated charitable purpose or cause; 
(2)  The sponsoring organization holds a current and valid policy of insurance providing compensation for any bodily injury to any member or participant or member of the general public suffering bodily liability arising out of the activity of solicitation in an amount not less than $2,000,000.00 single limit or its equivalent. The city shall be an additional named insured on such policy during all solicitation periods and the sponsoring organization shall provide the city with a certificate from the insurer to that effect; 
(3)  Any person or persons involved in such charitable solicitation must be over the age of 18 years and execute and deliver a wavier and release of any liability in favor of the city prior to solicitation; 
(4)  No location shall be permitted which shall be in violation of, or cause a violation of, state law. No location shall be permitted other than the location approved by the chief of the Chatsworth Police Department or his delegate; 
(5)  No permit shall allow the permitted activity at any time other than on a Saturday between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m.; 
(6)  As a condition for obtaining the permit, the applicant and sponsoring organization shall publicize in the legal organ of Murray County, Georgia, not less than one week prior to the date of the sale or solicitation that it shall be engaged in such solicitation giving the date, the hours of such activity, and the location. 
(7)  Any sponsoring organization or person seeking a permit for charitable solicitation under this section shall file for such permit on forms to be specified and provided by the chief of the Chatsworth Police Department and shall pay a $25.00 application-processing fee. 
(8)  No person or sponsoring organization shall be provided more than six permits during any calendar year. 
(c)  Penalties. Any person who sells any goods or services or solicits for the contribution of money for charitable purposes or otherwise in, along, upon, or over the public streets, roads, alleys or thoroughfares of the city in violation of this section shall be fined up to $250.00 for each offense upon conviction in the municipal court of the City of Chatsworth. 
( Ord. of 1-3-11(2) ) 
Secs. 13-8—13-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Sections 1—6 of an ordinance adopted Apr. 4, 1994 was not specifically amendatory to the Code. Said ordinance has been designated as §§ 13-20—13-25 and is included herein at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 13-20. - Short title. 
This article shall be known as the "Street Excavations Ordinance of the City of Chatsworth." 
(Ord. of 4-4-94, § 1) 
Sec. 13-21. - Terms defined. 
For purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, wording and their derivations shall have the meaning set forth herein. 
Applicant is any person making a written application to the mayor and council for an excavation permit hereunder. 
City is the City of Chatsworth. 
Excavation work is the excavation and other work permitted under an excavation permit and required to be performed under this article. 
Mayor and council is the governing body of the City of Chatsworth. 
Permittee is any person who has been granted and has in full force and effect an excavation permit issued hereunder. 
Person is any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, other governmental entity or authority or any organization of any kind. 
Street is any street, highway, sidewalk, alley, or other public way or public grounds in the city. 
Street superintendent is the appointed supervisor of the City of Chatsworth Street Department. 
(Ord. of 4-4-94, § 2) 
Sec. 13-22. - Unlawful to excavate without permit. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or entity to dig up, break, excavate, tunnel, undermine, or in any manner alter any city street, public alley, or sidewalk or to make or cause to be made any excavation in or under the surface of any city street, public alley, or sidewalk for any purpose or to place deposit, or leave upon any street any earth or any other excavated material obstructing or tending to interfere with the person shall have obtained a permit therefor in advance from the street superintendent, or his or her designee. A condition of the permit shall be that all work shall be accomplished in accordance with all applicable specification promulgated by the city street department from time to time, as amended. 
(Ord. of 4-4-94, § 3; Ord. of 4-2-2001, § 1) 
Sec. 13-23. - Issuance of a permit. 
An applicant shall make a written application to the street superintendent for the issuance of an excavation permit at least one full business day prior to the time in which the applicant desires to commence an excavation. Such written application may be received by and processed by the city clerk and shall be upon such forms as provided by the city clerk. 
(Ord. of 4-4-94, § 4; Ord. of 4-2-2001, § 2) 
Sec. 13-24. - Completion of excavation; damage to existing improvements. 
The permittee shall return any city street, public alley, or sidewalk to its condition immediately preceding the excavation work upon completion thereof. In the event that an excavation or removed portion of a city street, public alley, or sidewalk is not satisfactorily replaced and approved by the street superintendent or his or her designee, the city shall proceed immediately to repair or to replace said excavation or removed portion of said city street, public alley, or sidewalk at the expense of the application, and/or property owner or record for whose benefit said permit was granted. 
(Ord. of 4-4-94, § 5; Ord. of 4-2-2001, § 3) 
Sec. 13-25. - Failure to comply. 
Failure to comply with the terms of this article shall be cause for refusal to grant any future permit to any person until such person shall post a surety bond for the performance of any liabilities hereunder and for any future work to be performed under any future application. Said surety shall be in an amount satisfactory to the mayor and council and reasonably related to the excavation work to be performed and with surety satisfactory to the mayor and council. 
(Ord. of 4-4-94, § 6) 
Secs. 13-26—13-29. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY. 

Sec. 13-30. - Intent and purposes. 
The City of Chatsworth is vitally concerned with the use, construction within, and occupancy of all rights-of-way in the city as such rights-of-way are a valuable and limited resource which must be utilized to promote the public health, safety, welfare, and economic development of the city and to protect public work infrastructure. Therefore, the city, under the authority of the Laws and Constitution of the State of Georgia, including but not limited to Article 9, Section. 1, paragraphs 2 and 3 of the Georgia Constitution, O.C.G.A §36-35-3, and O.C.G.A §32-4-92(10), has adopted this ordinance for the purpose of regulating public and private entities which use the city rights-of-way. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-31. - Scope. 
The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all utilities and facilities occupying the right- of-way as provided herein. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-32. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations have the meanings set forth herein. The words "shall" and "will" are mandatory and "may" is permissive. Words not defined shall be given their common and ordinary meaning. References hereafter to "sections" are, unless otherwise specified, references to sections in this article. Defined terms remain defined terms whether or not capitalized. 
City means the City of Chatsworth, Georgia. 
Codified ordinances means the codified ordinances of the City of Chatsworth, Georgia. 
Construct means, but shall not be limited to, dig, bore, tunnel, trench, excavate, obstruct, install or remove signs, or facilities, other than landscaping or ornamental plantings, in, on, above, within, over, below, under or through any part of the rights-of-way. Construct shall also include the act of opening and/or cutting into the surface of any paved or improved surface that is any part of the right-of-way. 
Construction means, but shall not be limited to, the act or process of digging, boring, tunneling, trenching, excavating, obstructing, installing or removing signs or facilities, other than landscaping or ornamental plantings, in, on, above, within, over, below, under, or through any part of the rights-of-way. Construction shall also include the act of opening, boring, and/or cutting into the surface of any part of the right-of-way. 
Director means the road superintendent of the City of Chatsworth, Georgia, or his or her designee. 
Emergency means a condition that poses a clear and immediate danger to life, health, or safety of a person, or of significant damage of loss of real or personal property. 
Facility or facilities means any tangible thing, including but not limited to pipes, mains, conduits, cables, wires, poles, towers, traffic and other signals, and other equipment, appurtenances, appliances and future technology of any utility in, on, along, over, or under any part of the rights-of-way within the city. 
Facilities representative(s) means the specifically identified agent(s)/employee(s) of a utility who are authorized to direct field activities of that utility and serve as official notice agent(s) for facilities related information. Utility shall be required to make sure at least one of its facilities representatives available at all times to receive notice of, and immediately direct response to, facilities related emergencies or situations. 
FCC means the Federal Communications Commission or any successor thereto. 
Permit means an authorization which grants permission to conduct specific regulated activities on, in, over, under or within any public right-of-way, and which may be subject to conditions specified in a written agreement with the city or in a related provision of this Code of Ordinances. 
Right(s)-of-way means the surface and space in on above, within, over, below, under or through any real property in which the city has an interest in law or equity whether held in fee, or other estate or interest, or as a trustee for the public, including, but not limited to any public street, boulevard, road, highway freeway, lane, alley, court, sidewalk, parkway, or any other place, area, or real property owned by or under the legal or equitable control of the city, now or hereafter, that consistent with the purposes for which it was dedicated, may be used for the purposes of constructing, operating, repairing or replacing facilities. 
Service(s) means the offering of any service by a utility for a fee directly to the public, or to such classes of users as to be effectively available directly to the public, or alternatively, the provision of any service by a utility between two or more points for a proprietary purpose to a class of users other than the general public. 
Service agreement means a valid license agreement, service agreement, franchise agreement, or operating agreement issued by the city or state pursuant to law and accepted by a utility or entered into by and between the city and a utility, which allows such utility to operate or provide service within the geographic limits of the city. 
Street or streets means the surface of, as well as the spaces above and below; any and all the streets, alleys, avenues, roads, bridges, tunnels and public places of the city within the corporate limits of the city, as the same now exist or may be hereafter extended or altered, and any location thereon, thereover or thereunder; and any portion thereof. 
Transfer means the disposal by the utility, directly or indirectly, by gift, assignment, sale, merger, consolidation, or otherwise; of more than 50 percent at one time of the ownership or controlling interest in the facilities, or of more than 50 percent cumulatively over the term of a written approval of registration of such interests to a corporation, partnership, limited partnership, trust, or association, or person or group of persons acting in concert. 
Unused facilities means facilities located in the rights-of-way which have remained unused for 12 a plan detailing the procedure by which the utility intends to begin actively using such facilities within the next 12 months, or that it has a potential purchaser or user of the facilities who will be actively using the facilities within the next 12 months, or, that the availability of such facilities is required by the utility to adequately and efficiently operate its facilities. 
Utility or utilities means all privately, publicly, or cooperatively owned systems for producing, transmitting, or distributing communication, data, information, telecommunication, cable television, video services, power, electricity, light, heat, gas, oil, crude products, water/sewer, steam, fire and police signals, traffic control devices, and street lighting systems and housing or conduit for any of the foregoing; which directly or indirectly serve the public or any part thereof. The term "utility" may also be used to refer to the owner, operator, utility, service, contractor or subcontractor, or any agent thereof, of any above-described utility or utility facility. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-33. - Registration required. 
Each utility which occupies, uses, or has facilities in the rights-of-way at the time of passage of this article, including by lease, sublease, or assignment, to operate facilities located in the rights-of-way, unless specifically exempted by state or federal law or this Code, shall file a registration statement with the department within 90 days of the effective date of this article. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-34. - Registration procedure. 
The registration information provided to the city shall be on a form approved by the city and include, but not be limited to: 
(1)  The name, legal status (i.e. partnership, corporation, etc.), street address, email address, and telephone and facsimile numbers of the utility filing the registration statement (the "registrant"). If the registrant is not the owner of the facility in the right of way, the registration shall include the name, street address, email address if applicable, and telephone and facsimile numbers of the owner; 
(2)  The name, street address, email address if applicable and telephone and facsimile numbers of one or more facilities representative(s). Current information regarding how to contact the facilities representative(s) in an emergency shall be provided at the time of filing a registration and shall be updated as necessary to assure accurate contact information is available to the city at all times; 
(3)  A copy, if requested, of the utility's certificate of authority (or other acceptable evidence of authority to operate) from the Georgia Public Service Commission and/or the FCC and any other similar approvals, permits, or agreements. 
(4)  A copy, if requested, of the service agreement, if applicable or other legal instrument that authorizes the utility to use or occupy the right-of-way for the purpose described in the registration. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-35. - Incomplete registration. 
If a registration is incomplete, the director shall notify the registrant and shall provide a reasonable period of time not more than 90 days, in which to complete the registration. If a registration is complete, the director shall so notify the utility in writing. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-36. - Acceptance of the registration shall not convey title in the rights-of-way. 
Acceptance of the registration is only the nonexclusive, limited right to occupy rights-of-way in the city for the limited purposes stated in the acceptance. Acceptance of the registration does not excuse a utility from obtaining permits required by city ordinances nor from obtaining appropriate access or pole attachment agreements before using the facilities of others, including the city. Acceptance of the registration does not excuse a utility from notifying the city of construction as required herein. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-37. - Facilities in place without registration. 
Beginning one year after the effective date of this article, any facilities or part of a facility found in a right-of-way for which registration is required but has not been obtained, unless specifically exempted by law, and for which no valid service agreement exists with the city, may be deemed to be a nuisance and an unauthorized use of the rights-of-way. The city may exercise any remedies or rights it has at law or in equity, including, but not limited to abating the nuisance, taking possession of the facilities, evicting the utility from the right-of-way, prosecuting the violator, and/or any other remedy provided by city ordinance or otherwise allowed in law or in equity. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-38. - Permit required. 
It shall be unlawful for any utility to excavate or to construct, install, maintain, renew, remove or relocate facilities in, on, along, over or under the public roads of the city without a utility permit in accordance with the terms of this article. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-39. - Permit procedures. 
Utility permits shall be obtained from the director (or such other person as the city clerk may designate) upon application made on forms prescribed by the city. The written application shall include the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the utility; 
(2)  The nature, extent, and location of any work proposed to be done, along with satisfactory plans as attachments showing in detail the location of the proposed facility or operations as described in the permit application. The plans shall show the size or capacity of Facilities to be installed; their relationship to street features such as right-of-way lines; pavement edge, structures, etc., horizontal and vertical clearance to critical elements of the roadway and any other information necessary to evaluate the impact on the street and its operation; 
(3)  The name and address of the person or firm who is to do such work; 
(4)  The name, street address, email address if applicable and telephone and facsimile numbers of one or more facilities representatives). 
(5)  The projected dates for the work to be started and finished; 
(6)  An indemnity bond or other acceptable security in an amount to be set by the city to pay any damages to any part of the city road system or other city property or to any city employee or member of the public: caused by activity or work of the utility performed under authority of the permit issued; 
(7)  A copy, if requested of the registrant's certificate of authority (or other acceptable evidence of authority to operate) from the Georgia Public Service Commission and/or the FCC and any other similar approvals, permits, or agreements; and 
(8)  A copy, if requested, of the service agreement, if applicable or other legal [agreements] that authorizes the utility to use or occupy the right-of-way for the purpose described in the application. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-40. - Permit fees. 
Fees shall be determined by the director, subject to the approval by resolution of the city council. A fee schedule shall be available at the offices of the director and the city clerk and open for public inspection. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-41. - Issuance of permit. 
If the director determines the applicant has satisfied the following requirements, the director may issue a permit. 
(1)  Whether issuing of the approval will be consistent with this chapter; and 
(2)  Whether applicant has submitted a complete application and has secured all certificates and other authorizations required by law, if applicable, in order to construct facilities in the manner proposed by the applicant; and 
(3)  The impact on safety, visual quality of the streets, traffic-flow, and other users of the right of way and the difficulty and length of time of the project, construction or maintenance. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-42. - Emergency situations. 
(1)  Each utility shall, as soon as reasonably practicable, notify the director of any event regarding its facilities which it considers to be an emergency. The utility may proceed to take whatever actions are necessary in order to respond to the emergency. A utility who engages in an emergency excavation shall take all reasonable precautions to avoid or minimize damage to any existing facilities. 
(2)  In the event that the city becomes aware of an emergency regarding utility facilities, the city may attempt to contact the' affected utility or facilities representative. The city may take whatever action it deems necessary in order to respond to the emergency, including cut or move any of the wires, cables, amplifiers, appliances, or other parts of the facilities. The city shall not incur any liability to the utility, for such emergency actions, and the cost of such shall be paid by each utility affected by the emergency. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-43. - Effective period of permit. 
(1)  Each permit shall have a set commencement and expiration date based on information provided in the applicant's permit application. 
(2)  The permit shall remain in place construction is completed or until its expiration date unless the utility is in default. The director may give written notice of default to a utility if it is [determined] that a utility has: 
a.  Violated any provision or requirement of the issuance or acceptance of a permit application or any law of the city, state, or federal government; 
b.  Attempted to evade any provision or requirement of this chapter; 
c.  Practiced any fraud or deceit upon the city; or 
d.  Made a material misrepresentation or omission of fact in its permit application. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-44. - Cancellation for cause. 
If a utility fails to cure a default within 20 working days after such notice is provided to the utility by the city, then such default shall be a material breach and city may exercise any remedies or rights it has at law or in equity to terminate the permit. If the director decides there is cause or reason to terminate, the following procedure shall be followed: 
(1)  City shall serve a utility with a written notice of the reason or cause for proposed termination and shall allow a utility a minimum of 15 calendar days to cure its breach. 
(2)  If the utility fails to cure within 15 calendar days, the city may declare the permit terminated. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-45. - Expiration of permit. 
If work is not begun within six months of the date of issuance, the permit will automatically expire. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-46. - Utility accommodation manual adopted. 
The 1988 Utility Accommodation Policy and Standards manual, including an references contained therein to codes, rules, regulations, schedules, forms and appendix items, except Appendix B (permit forms and supporting documents), promulgated by the State of Georgia Department of Transportation, as may be amended from tine to time, is hereby adopted by reference and incorporated in the article as if fully set forth herein, subject to the amendments and modification contained in this chapter. A copy of the manual shall be maintained at the offices of the director or his designee and open for public inspection. Any conflicts between the. provisions of this ordinance and the manual shall be resolved in favor of the manual. References to state personnel, agencies, and fees shall be interpreted, where required, as meaning the City of Chatsworth municipal equivalents. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-47. - Protection of traffic and roadway. 
Unless specifically provided in the permit, no utility may occupy the city rights-of-way unless sufficient space is available so that the free flow and safety of traffic and other capacity considerations are not unduly impaired and the installation does not prevent the department from reasonably maintaining the streets, structures, traffic control devices, and other appurtenant facilities, and further provided that maintenance and operations of the facilities do not jeopardize the traffic, street structure, other users of the right of way or the right of way itself. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-48. - Grading. 
If the grades or lines of any street within the city right of way are changed at any time by the city during the term of the permit and this change involves an area in which the utility's facilities are located, then the utility shall, at its own cost and expense and upon the request of the city upon reasonable notice, protect or promptly alter or relocate the facilities, or any part thereof, so as to conform with such new grades or lines. In the event the utility refuses or neglects to so protect, alter, or relocate all or part of the facilities, the city shall have the right to break: through, remove, alter, or relocated all or any part of the facilities without any liability to the utility and the utility shall pay to the city the costs incurred in connection with such breaking through, removal, alteration, or relocation. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-49. - Installation of poles and other wireholding structures and relocation. 
Unless otherwise provided in a valid service agreement, no placement of any pole or wireholding structure of the utility is to be considered a vested interest in the right-of-way, and such poles or structures are to be removed, relocated underground, or modified by the utility at its own expense whenever the city determines that the public convenience would be enhanced thereby. The facilities shall be so located and installed as to cause minimum interference with the rights and convenience of property owners. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-50. - No blasting or excavation except under certain circumstances. 
As provided in O.C.G.A § 25-9-6 (the Georgia Utility Facility Protection Act) and other applicable state law currently in place or as amended, no utility shall commence, perform, or engage in blasting or in excavating with mechanized excavating facilities unless and until the utility planning the blasting or excavating has given 48 hours notice by submitting a locate request to the utility protection center, beginning the next working day after such notice is provided, excluding hours during days other than working days. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-51. - Repairs to rights-of-way. 
Each utility shall be responsible for the cost of repairing any facilities in the rights-of-way and adjoining property or other facilities which it or its facilities damage. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-52. - Restoration of rights-of-way. 
A utility shall be liable, at its own cost and expense, to replace, restore or repair, any street, facilities or property or structure thereon, thereunder, thereover or adjacent thereto that may become disturbed or damaged as a result of the construction or installation, operation, upgrade, repair or removal of facilities to a condition as good as or better than its condition before the work performed by the utility that caused such disturbance or damage. If the utility does not commence such replacement or repair after 20 days following written notice from the city, the city or the owner of the affected structure or property may make such replacement or repair and the utility shall pay the reasonable and actual cost of the same. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-53. - Inspection. 
The utility shall make the construction site available to the director to all others as authorized by law for inspection at all reasonable times during the execution and upon completion of the construction. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-54. - Stop work order. 
At any time, including the time of inspection, the director may order the immediate cessation of any work which poses a serious threat to the health, safety, or welfare of the public violates any law, or which violates the terms and conditions of the permit and/or this article or issue an order to correct work which does not conform to the permit and/or applicable standards, conditions or codes. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-55. - Completion. 
When the construction under any permit is completed, the utility shall notify the department. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-56. - Additional permits required. 
The utility shall obtain all construction, building or other permits or approvals as according to city ordinance, state or federal law. In addition, a permittee shall comply with all requirements of laws, shall complete work in a way as to not cause any unnecessary or unauthorized obstructions of sidewalks, streets, waterways or railways, and is responsible for all work done in the rights-of-way regardless of who performs the work. No rights-of-way obstruction or excavation may be performed when seasonally prohibited or when conditions are unreasonable for such work, except in the emergency as defined herein. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-57. - Penalties. 
Every utility convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter shall punished by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00 per violation. Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the city may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief, and revocation of licenses or permits. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Sec. 13-58. - Reservation of regulatory police powers. 
(a)  The city by issuing a written approval of registration under this chapter, does not surrender or to any extent lose, waive, impair, or lessen the lawful powers and rights, which it has now or may be hereafter vested in the city under the constitution and laws of the. United States, State of Georgia and the City Charter, and under the provisions of the city's codified ordinances to regulate the use of the rights-of-way. The utility, by applying for and being issued a written permit, is deemed to acknowledge that all lawful powers and rights, regulatory power, or police power, or otherwise as are or the same may be from time to time vested in or reserved to the city, shall be in full force and effect and subject to the exercise thereof by the city at any time. A utility is deemed to acknowledge that its interests are subject to the regulatory and police powers of the city to adopt and enforce general ordinances necessary to the safety and welfare of the public and is deemed to agree to comply with all applicable general laws enacted by the city pursuant to such powers. In particular, all utilities shall comply with city zoning and other land use requirements pertaining to the placement and specifications of facilities. 
(b)  This article shall become effective following its enactment by the mayor and council of the City of Chatsworth, the public health, safety, and welfare requiring it. 
(c)  All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. 
(d)  It is hereby declared to be the intention of the mayor and council of the City of Chatsworth that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses, and phrases of this article are severable and if any section, paragraph, sentence, clause, or phrase shall be declared unconstitutional or otherwise invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect any of the remaining sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses, or phrases herein. 
( 8-3-09(1) ) 
Chapter 14 - TRAFFIC[1]

Cross reference— Creation of noise by vehicles, § 7-5(1),(6),(7),(8). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Adoption of state law by reference. 
(a)  Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-6-372, §§ 40-6-1 through 40-6-395, known as the "Uniform Rules of the Road," are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of this municipality with like effect as if recited herein. 
(b)  Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. 
(Ord. of 3-1-82) 
State Law reference— Jurisdiction of municipal court of violations of driver's license statute, O.C.G.A. § 40-5-124; of unregistered motor vehicle statute, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-22. 
Sec. 14-2. - Dangerous driving. 
(a)  Any person who drives a motor vehicle upon any street of the city at a speed or in a manner so as to endanger, or likely to endanger, life, limb, or property of any person shall be guilty of dangerous driving, in violation of this Code. 
(b)  Dangerous driving within the meaning of this section shall be deemed to include the following offenses, which are expressly prohibited: 
(1)  Driving a motor vehicle when not under complete control, or with inadequate or improperly adjusted brakes. 
(2)  Driving to the left of the center of the street. 
(3)  Passing or attempting to pass two other vehicles abreast, moving in the same direction. 
(4)  Backing into the line of traffic without ascertaining if the way is clear. 
(5)  A failure to give adequate and timely signals of intention to turn and/or slow down or stop. 
(6)  Exceeding a reasonable speed under the circumstances of traffic conditions obtaining at the time. 
(7)  Passing other vehicles going in the same direction while crossing at an intersection, or while pedestrians are passing, or about to pass, in front of either of such vehicles. 
(8)  Driving a vehicle out of an alley, or from behind a building, across a sidewalk into a street without bringing such vehicle to a full stop immediately before crossing such sidewalk, and sounding the horn. 
(Ord. of 9-3-51, § 2) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-390. 
Sec. 14-3. - Riding or driving on sidewalks. 
It shall not be lawful for any person to ride, propel or run any bicycle or motor vehicle on any sidewalk, except to cross the sidewalk on a driveway. 
(Code 1926, § 197)

(3)  From North Sixth Avenue (C.S. 605) to State Route 2, 0.27 mile, 35 miles per hour. (Ord. of 3-1-82; Ord. No. 9-9-93, 12-13-93; Ord. No. 3-1-95, 5-1-95) 
Green Road:

No. 9-9-93, 12-13-93)

Cross reference— Speed of trains, § 14-20. 
Sec. 14-5. - No-parking zones. 
(a)  There shall be no parking on the alley between Second Avenue and Third Avenue from Fort Street to Market Street, a distance of four hundred (400) feet, except for deliveries only. (Ord. of 6-1-87, § 1) 
(b)  There shall be no parking on Third Avenue and immediately in front of the courthouse steps leading to Third Avenue, the zone to be 16 feet wide and to be plainly marked across Third Avenue; within such marked space no vehicle shall be permitted to park on either the east or west side of Third Avenue. (Ord. of 2-3-41(1)) 
(c)  There shall be no parking on either the west side or east side of Third Avenue (U.S. Highway 411), from the north side of Cherokee Street, north to the end of the present curbing and guttering at the north line of land of Clyde Powell. (Ord. of 10-5-70) 
(d)  There shall no parking on the east side of State Route 61 (U.S. Highway 411) from mile post 12.492 (72 feet south of Cherokee Street) to milepost 12.505 (the southeast corner of Cherokee Street and State Route 61), this area being in front of the Chatsworth Times Newspaper office. (Ord. of 7-6-82) 
(e)  There shall be no parking on that portion of first Avenue located north from its intersection with the southern right-of-way of Peachtree Street (if extended) to the northern right-of-way of Walnut Street (if extended); that portion of Peachtree Street located east of the eastern right-of-way of Second Avenue to the western right-of-way of First Avenue; that portion of Walnut Street located east of the eastern right-of-way of Second Avenue to the western right-of-way of First Avenue; and that portion of Second Avenue located north of the southern right-of-way of Peachtree Street (if extended) to the northern right-of-way of Walnut Street (if extended). Provided that, prohibition of parking on the above described roadways shall only apply during the hours between 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. 
(Ord. of 2-3-41(1); Ord. of 10-5-70; Ord. of 4-11-77(1), § 1; Ord. of 7-6-82; Ord. of 6-1-87, § 1; Ord. of 9-9-2002, § 1) 
Sec. 14-6. - Truck routes. 
It shall be unlawful for a truck with a load capacity in excess of one (1) ton to be driven on the following designated streets at any time, except for deliveries on such streets: 
(1)  Green Road from city limits to Market Street, 
(2)  Market Street from Fourth Avenue to Charles Road, 
(3)  Chestnut Street from Green Road to Third Avenue, 
(4)  Old Dalton Ellijay Road from city limits to intersection with G.I. Maddox Parkway, 
(5)  Fourth Avenue from Fort Street to Meir Street, 
(6)  Fourth Avenue from Market Street to end of street, 
(7)  Fifth Avenue, 
(8)  Sixth Avenue, 
(9)  Seventh Avenue, 
(10)  Ninth Avenue, 
(11)  Olive Street, 
(12)  Pine Street, 
(13)  Thompson Street, 
(14)  Cherokee Street, 
(15)  Peachtree Street, 
(16)  Walnut Street, 
(17)  Oak Street, 
(18)  Locust Street, 
(19)  Second Avenue from Pine Street south to intersection of Third Avenue, 
(20)  Second Avenue from Market Street to intersection of Hyde Tyler Road, 
(21)  Charles Road, 
(22)  Elm Street, 
(23)  Long Avenue, 
(24)  Tenth Avenue. 
(Ord. of 3-3-86(2)) 
Secs. 14-7—14-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RAILROADS 

Sec. 14-20. - Speed limit. 
The speed limits of trains of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad Company, Atlanta Division, a branch of the Seaboard Systems Railroad, running through the city are hereby set at 45 miles per hour from 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. from milepost C 376.4 to milepost C 377.6 and at 60 miles per hour from 10:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. from milepost C 376.4 to milepost C 377.6. 
(Code 1926, § 222; Ord. of 9-12-83) 
Sec. 14-21. - Blowing whistle. 
It shall be an offense to run a train within the city after approaching within 100 yards of the first public crossing, without plainly and distinctly blowing the whistle or sounding the horn while the train is in motion. 
(Code 1926, § 220) 
Sec. 14-22. - Obstructing crossing. 
It shall be unlawful to obstruct any public street or crossing by engines or cars of any description being allowed to stand still on any portion of the ground laid out for such street or crossing for the space of 15 minutes, or by switching engines or cars within the limits of such street or crossing, or in any other way to obstruct or to interfere with the free passage of persons or vehicles on any part of such street; it being the true intent and meaning of this section that railroads have the necessary right of passing their engines and trains over such streets or crossings in their actual and necessary business, but that they have no right to obstruct the streets beyond their actual necessity of passing; and any building of switches or using of any street for switching cars or allowing cars of engines to stand thereon shall be a violation of this section. 
(Code 1926, § 221) 
Sec. 14-23. - Persons subject to punishment. 
The engineer or person in charge of any engine, as well as the conductor or other person under whose order the act is done, and all other persons concerned in violating any section of this article, shall be punished as prescribed in section 1-8. 
(Code 1926, § 223) 
Secs. 14-24—14-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DOWNTOWN PARKING DISTRICT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Sections A—G of an ordinance adopted Apr. 4, 1994 was not specifically amendatory to the Code. Said ordinance has been designated as §§ 14-40—14-46 and included herein at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 14-40. - Short title. 
This article shall be known and may be cited as ``The Downtown Parking District Ordinance.'' 
(Ord. of 4-4-94, § A) 
Sec. 14-41. - Purpose and intent. 
The purpose of this article is to assure that all residents of and visitors to the city have equal access to parking spaces within the herein created downtown parking district. The intent of this ordinance is to create a two hour time limit parking zone not limited in scope to individual parking spaces. Said two hour parking zone shall be known as the downtown parking district. 
(Ord. of 4-4-94, § B) 
Sec. 14-42. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this article the following terms, phrases, wording and their derivations shall have the meaning set forth herein: 
Automobile is a self-propelled vehicle used for transportation. 
City is the City of Chatsworth. 
Downtown parking district is all the parking spaces along the side of the streets within the city limits of the city except those parking spaces immediately surrounding the Murray County Courthouse and except those parking spaces on municipal property designated for public parking. 
No parking zone is any area within the downtown parking district in which parking shall not be permitted unless otherwise indicated. Any such area shall be identified by appropriately erected signs giving notice thereof. 
Parking spaces is all side street parking within the city. 
Person is any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, other governmental entity or authority or any organization of any kind. 
Street is any street, highway, sidewalk, or other public way or public grounds in the city. 
(Ord. of 4-4-94, § C) 
Sec. 14-43. - Two-hour parking. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park an automobile for more than two hours within the downtown parking district between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday. The moving of an automobile from space to space within the downtown parking district is contemplated and is hereby specifically prohibited after the two-hour time limit has expired. 
(Ord. of 4-4-94, § D) 
Sec. 14-44. - No parking zone. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park an automobile within an appropriately designated no parking zone. 
(Ord. of 4-4-94, § E) 
Sec. 14-45. - Enforcement. 
Enforcement of this article shall be provided by the Chatsworth Police Department. 
(Ord. of 4-4-94, § F) 
Sec. 14-46. - Fines, penalties and procedure. 
Any person who parks an automobile within the downtown parking district in violation of this article shall be cited and fined $25.00. Said fine shall be due and payable to the city at the Chatsworth Police Department within 30 days from the date of said citation. Persons failing to voluntarily appear and pay said $25.00 fine(s) may be cited to the municipal court of Chatsworth, Georgia, for failure to pay such fine. 
Any person convicted in the municipal court of Chatsworth, Georgia, of failure to pay any fine(s) assessed under this article shall promptly pay into the court any past due fines along with $25.00 per unpaid fine, and any court costs generated by failure to pay said fine(s). 
( Ord. of 4-4-11(1), § 1 ) 
ARTICLE IV. - IMPOUNDING VEHICLES 

Sec. 14-47. - Impounding vehicles authorized. 
Under the following circumstances, the chief of police, or his designee, shall be authorized to order the impoundment of any vehicle to an appropriate location: 
(1)  Any vehicle left abandoned and unattended due to the arrest of the driver thereof, when no other responsible, lawful driver designated by the owner shall be readily available; 
(2)  Any vehicle that is evidence in any ongoing law enforcement investigation; 
(3)  Any vehicle not properly tagged, titled, registered, or insured; 
(4)  Any vehicle inoperable or abandoned pursuant to section 14-50. 
(Ord. of 5-4-2009, § 1) 
Sec. 14-48. - Delegation of authority. 
The chief of police may delegate his authority set forth herein with respect to impounding vehicles to any certified peace officer employed by the police department. 
(Ord. of 5-4-2009, § 1) 
Sec. 14-49. - Responsibility for towing or other charge(s). 
Any wrecker bill, towing, storage, or other related charge(s) for a vehicle impounded pursuant to this article shall be paid by the owner of such vehicle. Such fees shall not exceed the maximum towing fees permitted by the Georgia Public Service Commission and shall be approved by the chief of police. 
(Ord. of 5-4-2009, § 1) 
Sec. 14-50. - Inoperable and abandoned vehicles. 
No vehicle shall be abandoned or left unattended upon a public street or highway or other public property, whether operable or not, for a period of more than 24 hours. Any vehicle so abandoned or left inoperable may be impounded by the police department at the owner's expense, and the owner may be subject to fine. 
(Ord. of 5-4-2009, § 1) 
Sec. 14-51. - Unauthorized removal of impounded vehicles. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to remove or attempt to remove a towed and stored vehicle from the place of storage designated by the chief of police. 
(Ord. of 5-4-2009, § 1) 
Appendix A - ZONING[1] 
ZONING ORDINANCE 
CITY OF CHATSWORTH, GEORGIA 
An Ordinance of the City of Chatsworth, Georgia, regulating the location, height, bulk, number of stories and size of buildings and other structures, the size of yards, courts, and other open spaces, the percentage of lot that may be occupied, the density and distribution of population, the uses of buildings, structures, land and water for trade, industry, commerce, residences, recreation, public activities or other purposes, creating districts for said purposes and establishing the boundaries thereof; defining certain terms used herein; providing for the method and administration and amendment; creating and defining the powers and duties of the Board of Zoning Appeals; providing penalties and remedies for violation; and repealing all amendments thereto and all conflicting Ordinances; and for other purposes. 
AN ORDINANCE OF THE CITY OF CHATSWORTH, GEORGIA: 
REGULATING THE LOCATION, CONSTRUCTION, AND USE OF BUILDINGS, STRUCTURES, AND LAND: AND FOR DIVIDING THE INCORPORATED AREA INTO DISTRICTS FOR SUCH PURPOSES AND ESTABLISHING BOUNDARIES THEREFORE: PROVIDING FOR THE METHOD OF ADMINISTRATION AND AMENDMENT: AND PRESCRIBING PENALTIES FOR THE VIOLATION OF ITS PROVISIONS. 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. of 10-09, adopted October 2009 , amended appendix A in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Appendix A, articles I—XVII, and appendices A—C, pertained to Zoning. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. The zoning ordinance, dated October 2009, is set out herein as it appears in pamphlet, in substance and for the most part in form. Words and figures in brackets have been inserted by the editor. 
Cross reference— Planning commissions, § 12-1 et seq.; sign restrictions, § 4-5. 
State Law reference— Zoning Procedures Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - SHORT TITLE AND PURPOSE 

Section A. - Short Title. 
This Ordinance shall be known and may be cited as "The Zoning Ordinance of the City of Chatsworth, Georgia." 
( Ord. of 10-09 ) 
Section B. - Purpose and Intent. 
The purpose of this Ordinance is to establish minimum standards for the use of land and improvements thereon in the incorporated area of the City of Chatsworth, Georgia.
